emailColumn.title: Airvoice: Clean Air Solutions for Global Markets

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Dmitry Trubitsyn is the co-founder and international expansion leader of Airvoice, which encompasses Tion (air purification and ventilation) and CityAir (air quality monitoring). With a background in atmospheric physics and postgraduate studies, she has led the company's transformation from a small Siberian startup in 2006 to a 400+ employee group with operations across Russia, China, US, and India. She specializes in complex air quality management solutions for cities, industrial enterprises, and healthcare facilities.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: Successful tech expansion requires founder commitment - if you're not willing to spend significant time in a target market, don't enter it. Creating markets is fundamentally different from entering existing ones, requiring patience and educational approaches rather than competitive strategies. Local partnerships become critical in relationship-driven markets like India, where personal connections often outweigh product superiority. Cultural business practices matter immensely - from American 'small talk' rituals to Indian price sensitivity and decision timelines. Extended credibility-building periods are necessary, especially in B2B sales cycles that can span 1-2 years.

emails.subject: Initial Market Entry: Starting with a Vision of Clean Air üå¨Ô∏è
emails.body:
You asked about what influenced our decision to enter the international market, and our journey began in a rather interesting way.

Our first tech company started in 2006 in one Academic Town. Now called Tion, it was our initial venture after completing our postgraduate studies when we realized that being scientists wasn't the only way to make an impact. We focused exclusively on the home market at first, though we always had global ambitions since clean air is a universal need, not a country-specific problem. üåç

Tion now has about 400 employees and operates independently in the air purification and disinfection niche. About 10 years later (around 2014), while Tion was already established, we became interested in whether we could monitor and measure ambient air parameters to manage air quality better. This led to creating an internal division, which later became an independent business called CityAir. üè≠

CityAir develops and produces monitoring systems for air quality management at city and industrial enterprise levels. It's complex high-tech work involving sophisticated sensors, signal recovery algorithms, and atmospheric physics mathematics, all operating on a unified platform. üìä

After successfully solving these technological entrepreneurial challenges at home, we felt ready to test ourselves globally. It wasn't about market immaturity or financial ambitions - it was about challenging ourselves. Could we replicate our success internationally? In 2021, we established a new company in the US üá∫üá∏, which became our headquarters for all international operations. üíº

highlight.title: Extreme Local Conditions Require Complete Product Re-Engineering
highlight.description: Products designed for moderate pollution levels need fundamental redesign for extreme environments like India. Price localization and technical adaptation must happen simultaneously while maintaining effectiveness.

emails.subject: Choosing the US Market üá∫üá∏
emails.body:
You asked why we chose the US market over other potential options, and there were several key factors in our decision.

We were looking for a market that met multiple criteria. First, the US is incredibly diverse and essentially functions as more than just one market - it's a large territory where we could definitely apply our expertise. Second, we were drawn to the entrepreneurial culture and business environment. üíº

We had actually considered both the US and the Netherlands üá≥üá±. The choice came down to corporate culture and value systems. We feared other European countries might feel sluggish and slow, while the US seemed to have the entrepreneurial spirit we were looking for. ‚ö°

Having visited the US multiple times previously helped with this decision. Additionally, many of our team members are graduates of the Physics Department of Novosibirsk State University, and you can find NSU physics graduates at virtually every American university. This gave us a ready network of professional connections, which was particularly valuable since our work involves complex technological solutions. üéì

We had already collaborated with institutions like MIT on joint material science projects, so things were starting to progress naturally. When you have an existing network of contacts, a compatible corporate environment, and a cultural fit, it makes the decision much easier. ü§ù

While the Netherlands was also considered for its entrepreneurial spirit, it's simply smaller with fewer connections. Once we confirmed there were no major obstacles to entering the US market, we prioritized it based on scale and systematic approach. The US represented a larger, more independent opportunity. üìà

It's worth noting that we don't really enter existing markets - we create markets. When you're doing something innovative, you need to form the market from scratch, which is difficult to analyze in advance. Our approach was intuitive but logical - we knew our air quality solutions could be in demand in the US, even if there wasn't an established market for them yet. üöÄ

highlight.title: Network Effects Trump Market Size in Technical B2B Sales
highlight.description: Having existing professional relationships and cultural compatibility often matters more than pure market size, especially for complex technical solutions that require education and trust-building.

emails.subject: Market Entry Approach and Early Operations üèóÔ∏è
emails.body:
You asked about our strategy and first steps for entering the American market.

We began with business trips and pilot projects in 2018-2019, establishing the legal entity in 2021. We entered with two vertical products: systems for monitoring and controlling atmospheric air (targeting cities and industrial enterprises) and systems for monitoring, analyzing, and managing air quality at large facilities (targeting building owners, operators, and large employers). üè¢

Our first contacts came through individuals who had built Vernstad in Washington, DC. We launched pilots in several cities and real estate projects, though we didn't immediately work with industrial companies. As we gained traction, our presence in the US became more systematic and regular. üìç

We didn't create a formal business plan due to the high degree of uncertainty. Instead, we developed a set of critical objectives that needed to be accomplished or learned, drawing on our previous experience, including Tion's launch in China üá®üá≥. The approach was focused on clear goals rather than complicated plans. üéØ

Our strategy differed from our China experience in significant ways. In China, my partner Anton Zhuchkov took the lead, and we followed his guidance since he was on the ground. The Chinese market presented communication challenges because few people spoke English and negotiations were difficult due to cultural differences. üó£Ô∏è

For the US, I understood that I needed to be personally involved in building everything. For a small company like ours, we realized it was impossible to succeed without the founder or co-founder spending significant time in the market, especially with a B2B business involving both hardware and software where you're selling not just products but expertise. üîß

This 'founder-led' approach became a key criterion in our market selection - I needed to be willing to spend substantial time in the country we chose. Even if another market might have been more attractive from a business perspective, if I wasn't prepared to commit significant time there, we wouldn't go. ‚è∞

highlight.title: Founder Commitment Is the Ultimate Market Selection Filter
highlight.description: The most important market selection criteria isn't market size or opportunity - it's whether the founder is personally willing to spend significant time there. This commitment filter prevents over-expansion and ensures proper attention to market development.

emails.subject: Testing the Market and Building Relationships ü§ù
emails.body:
You asked about how we researched the American market and the timeline of our expansion.

Our initial visits weren't six-month or year-long relocations, but rather business trips lasting about a month each. The first trips were exploratory - while we had done some desk research to understand the market structure, the most valuable insights came from direct engagement. üìù

We scheduled meetings with potential clients and presented our solutions to gauge interest. This practical market research involved meeting people, discussing our offerings, collecting feedback, and adapting our approach. When we received enough positive responses indicating people were ready to work with us, we decided to formalize our presence by establishing a company. ‚úÖ

It took about three years from our first exploratory trips in 2018 to establishing the legal entity in 2021. This extended timeline was partly due to dividing our focus - we still had projects at home requiring attention, which prolonged the process. If we had committed 100% to the US market from the beginning, our progress would have been much faster. üöÄ

During those three years, we didn't have commercial sales - our product has a long sales cycle, sometimes up to two years. However, the feedback was consistently positive enough to justify continuing. Based on various metrics and our overall assessment, we concluded that with proper focus, we would definitely succeed. üìä

The commitment from potential clients was significant - when major corporations agree to pilot your technology with the intention to buy if the pilot is successful, that demonstrates serious interest. While these pilots weren't immediate sales, they represented clear steps toward commercial relationships. üè¢

The process was gradual. On our first business trip, we would meet someone who showed interest. We'd exchange information, return for follow-up meetings, and slowly move the relationship forward. We also participated in exhibitions and university events, organizing seminars that brought together local professors and researchers. üéì

highlight.title: Pilot Commitments Are More Valuable Than Market Research
highlight.description: When major corporations agree to pilot your technology with purchase intent, that's stronger validation than any market research. Extended sales cycles require patience, but serious pilot commitments indicate real market potential.

emails.subject: Building Networks and Sales Channels üåê
emails.body:
You asked about how we established our initial contacts with potential customers in the US.

Our first connections came through friends and mutual acquaintances. In our experience, we can find mutual connections with almost anyone, which made it easier to get started. These warm introductions were crucial in the beginning. ü§ù

We also experimented with cold outreach, hiring Anton Glotkov (who's now in London) and his team to help with this approach. While these cold calls didn't immediately convert to contracts, the positive responses - people's willingness to call, meet, talk, and move forward - gave us confidence. üìû

The choice to work with Anton wasn't particularly strategic - we knew each other from Academic Town and had crossed paths multiple times. When our warm introductions were working well, we recalled Anton's expertise in this area. While we did look at other options, our established relationship and mutual trust with Anton was valuable. We shared similar terminology and trusted each other, which meant we could focus our energy on the market rather than spending time synchronizing with a new contractor. üíº

We didn't consider hiring American contractors for this work. First, there's a misconception that native English speakers necessarily make better salespeople. Often, non-native speakers who are fluent can be more concise and clearer in their communication. Second, and more importantly, we were entering a nascent market without established experts. üå±

Since city-wide air monitoring and control systems represent an emerging field, there weren't specialized American contractors with specific expertise in this area. From our perspective, we were the experts in this market. While there were some competitors, it was still an undeveloped space without recognized leaders. üèÜ

When potential clients asked what we were doing, we had to explain that our solutions went beyond basic air quality measurements (like those in iPhones üì±) to provide professional decision-making tools for cities and industrial enterprises. üè≠

highlight.title: In Emerging Markets, Domain Expertise Beats Native Language Skills
highlight.description: When you're creating a new market category, having deep technical expertise matters more than hiring local sales talent. Non-native speakers with domain knowledge can often communicate more clearly than locals without technical background.

emails.subject: Geographic Focus and Expansion Strategy üìç
emails.body:
You asked about our geographic focus within the US and our approach to deadlines and metrics.

We concentrated on two main centers: the East Coast (New York and surrounding areas) and the West Coast (San Francisco and Silicon Valley). The East Coast had the highest concentration of potential customers and contacts, making it easier to start there. While we had promising leads on both coasts, we ultimately decided to focus on the East Coast based on the momentum we were building there. üóΩ

Our team in the US was quite small - primarily myself, sometimes with one or two others. With limited resources, we chose to concentrate our efforts where we were seeing the most traction. The plan was to establish ourselves solidly in one region before expanding to others, which would be much easier once we had a stable foundation. üéØ

Regarding deadlines, we didn't set a specific time frame after which we would abandon the US market if unsuccessful. We believed in our eventual success, but we did have criteria for decision-making. If progress remained stalled for an extended period and financing became unclear, we would need to reconsider. Our approach was to continue as long as we felt we were making sufficient progress and had the resources to support our activities. üìà

Had we spent three years actively working in the US without achieving anything substantial, our perception of the prospects might have changed. However, our sense of opportunity in the US was constantly growing. We were close to securing substantial contracts: in our industry a single contract can be worth around a million dollars annually. With several such contracts, the business becomes self-sustaining, allowing for further hiring, operations, and development. üí∞

The main reason we only approached opening a legal entity in 2021, three years after our initial exploration, was that we had resources at home supporting us. We weren't launching a completely new product but rather adapting one we had been working on for 15-18 years. With 500 people behind us (though not all directly involved), we had strong support for our US efforts, including impressive websites and UX/UI that resonated with customers. Most of our content creation happened at home, not America. üè†

highlight.title: Geographic Concentration Plus Home Base Support Accelerates Market Entry
highlight.description: Focusing on one region while leveraging existing home market capabilities allows small teams to compete effectively. Don't try to cover entire large markets initially - establish momentum in one area first.

emails.subject: Cultural Differences and Business Practices üé≠
emails.body:
You asked about cultural differences in business practices between the home and the US markets.

One significant advantage we discovered is that it's actually easier for small entrepreneurs in the US when dealing with corporations. Large corporations tend to look suspiciously at small contractors at home: a company with 50 people might be viewed as too small to be trusted. In the US, corporations routinely work with many more contractors than their counterparts. There's a much greater willingness to trust small companies with important components of their business. ü§ù

I remember a meeting with a major oil and gas company at their headquarters. We arrived in casual attire with our presentation, and found eight executives who had printed our materials and made detailed notes throughout. We were impressed by how prepared they were and the quality of communication. People not only spent time with us but listened carefully - a definite advantage of the US business environment. üëî

On the challenging side, there's much greater accountability for your commitments in the US. If you promise something will be ready by a certain date, it absolutely needs to be delivered as promised. Delays or changes can significantly damage your reputation. ‚è∞

We also noticed that being a non-local company created some initial hesitation - there's an assumption that such companies might be less reliable, might miss deadlines, or forget commitments. We had to prove that we didn't operate that way. üåç

Another cultural difference that initially confused us was the practice of 'small talk' before meetings. Americans often spend time discussing weather or other casual topics before getting to business. Our instinct was to say 'let's get down to business,' but we learned that skipping this social ritual could be perceived as offensive. This pattern is well-described in cultural studies like 'Culture Map' - from our experience, those observations are accurate. ‚òÄÔ∏è

Furthermore, we found that American business culture values preparation and professionalism highly, but also appreciates directness and efficiency once relationships are established. üìã

highlight.title: Cultural Business Rituals Matter More Than Product Features
highlight.description: Understanding and respecting cultural business practices like American 'small talk' can be more important than technical capabilities. Cultural competence directly impacts trust and relationship building.

emails.subject: Legal Structure and Timing Considerations ‚öñÔ∏è
emails.body:
You asked about our decision to establish a legal entity three years after beginning our market exploration.

For our initial activities, there was simply no need to create a legal entity immediately. We started as a CIS company exploring the market, and there were no issues with interacting and communicating with potential American clients without a US entity. We were transparent about our approach: we would first deliver value, and if necessary, establish a legal entity later. üè¢

This approach was completely acceptable to our American contacts. These were long-term contracts under discussion, so the understanding was that if we proceeded with significant business, we would set up the appropriate legal structure. The same applies with investors - at the pre-seed stage, you don't necessarily need a company already established. If there's mutual interest, you can create the entity when needed. üíº

Setting up a company can be done quickly online, so there was no advantage to doing it prematurely. As for reputation concerns, we found that being upfront about our status and plans was sufficient. üíª

When events in 2022 forced us to reconsider our global strategy, we already had an established US legal entity with two employees. Our pilots continued running, though we had to pause more ambitious expansion plans. Import restrictions and visa issues (I had been in the process of obtaining a visa but couldn't return, and have been under administrative review for 14 months) effectively put our US operations on hold at their current stage. ‚ö†Ô∏è

At that point, we needed to establish clear legal boundaries, and we couldn't operate in the US as we had previously. This led us to explore other markets where we could maintain momentum. üåç

The lesson here is that transparency about your legal status and future plans is often more valuable than premature entity creation. Most sophisticated clients understand that serious business relationships require proper legal structures, but they're willing to discuss opportunities before those structures exist. ü§ù

highlight.title: Transparency About Legal Status Beats Premature Entity Formation
highlight.description: Being honest about your legal structure timeline and plans builds more trust than rushing to create entities before you need them. Sophisticated clients understand business development processes.

emails.subject: Pivoting to India: Strategic Rationale üáÆüá≥
emails.body:
You asked about our decision to enter the Indian market after our US operations were put on hold.

There were three key reasons for choosing India. First and most obvious: air quality in India is notoriously poor, making it a perfect fit for our solutions. Combined with a growing economy and expanding middle class increasingly concerned about quality of life, the market opportunity was clear. Air and India are frequently mentioned in the same sentence, and our 18 years of experience in air quality management was directly applicable. üå´Ô∏è

Second, we found that India had fewer concerns about our origins than Western markets. In the current geopolitical climate, this removed a significant barrier to entry. üåç

The third and perhaps most decisive factor was finding the right partner. A woman from my town is married to an Indian man whose brother - a retired high-ranking military officer - became interested in becoming our partner. Without him, we likely wouldn't have proceeded despite the market's potential. He's now a businessman who serves as president of a well-known school community, bringing valuable connections and local expertise. ü§ù

Our approach to India was more systematic than our US entry. We immediately established a joint venture with a local CEO (the former chief of Honeywell India) and started hiring people to conduct meetings with potential customers. We also engaged marketing and PR agencies to support our efforts. üìà

We changed our approach because we immediately had a partner with whom we could do more. In India, having local partners is critical - you simply cannot function effectively without them. Even visiting different areas of the country is challenging without local support. The fact that we could immediately establish this foundation allowed us to move more aggressively than we had in the US. üöÄ

The Indian market is highly fragmented, and business relationships are strongly influenced by personal connections. If your salesperson isn't just from India but specifically from the relevant state or region, they'll be much more effective. The system of insiders and outsiders is pronounced - people naturally prefer to work with those from their own circles, even if the offerings are inferior. üë•

highlight.title: Market-Problem Fit Plus Partnership Quality Determines Entry Success
highlight.description: Having perfect market-problem fit isn't enough - you need the right local partners who understand regional nuances and have established networks. In relationship-driven markets, partner quality often matters more than product quality.

emails.subject: Operational Challenges in India üéØ
emails.body:
You asked about our specific experiences and challenges in the Indian market.

India presents several substantial challenges that entrepreneurs often underestimate. First, it's an extremely price-sensitive market. People tend to overestimate India's market size based on population, but in reality, the addressable market is much smaller due to this price sensitivity. If you don't understand how to work with pricing in this environment, you'll struggle significantly. üí∞

Second, everything in India moves exceptionally slowly. Any legal actions, agreements, or contract signings take much longer than what we're accustomed to elsewhere. This requires adjusting expectations and planning for extended timelines. ‚è∞

Third, it's virtually impossible to operate without a local partner unless you're a major corporation like Microsoft. Finding the right partner is critical - they must be trustworthy, have a good reputation, and be well-connected. This may be the most significant challenge of all, as partners must be chosen based on trust, which is difficult to establish quickly without existing connections. ü§ù

One of our most significant mistakes was underestimating the differences in management approaches between our team and our Indian partners. Despite our partners being relatively westernized and speaking the same business language, we discovered we had very different views on organizational structure and management systems. üè¢

This apparent similarity led us to pay insufficient attention to aligning our management approaches. We thought we were thinking the same way, but our experiences and backgrounds created significant differences. We should have spent more time discussing not just what we wanted to achieve, but how we would work together to achieve it. This oversight cost us efficiency and time. üíº

We've now begun explicitly addressing these differences, suggesting various management frameworks and practices that account for both our approach and the Indian context. Companies familiar with international operations often bring their own managing directors who understand how to navigate these differences, placing them in key operational roles while having a local CEO who serves as the face of the company externally. üåç

highlight.title: Similar Business Language Hides Deep Management Culture Differences
highlight.description: Partners who speak the same business language and appear westernized may still have fundamentally different management philosophies. Explicitly aligning on how you'll work together matters as much as what you'll achieve together.

emails.subject: Product Adaptation for Indian Market üîß
emails.body:
You asked about how we adapted our products for the Indian market specifically.

We have multiple product lines, each requiring different adaptations. Even for Breezer, which is conceptually our simplest product (compact ventilation units with advanced air purification), we had to make significant changes. These units were originally designed as high-end solutions for environments with moderate pollution, but India's extreme pollution levels (often reaching 500 micrograms of particles per cubic meter) required substantial modifications. While we didn't manufacture these devices ourselves, we provided detailed requirements for their adaptation based on our expertise in measuring and understanding air quality. üìä

For our monitoring platforms (both outdoor and indoor air management), we essentially recreated them for the Indian market. While we had core components developed previously, the specific products relevant to India are being developed based on continuous market feedback, which informs both long-term technology development plans and shorter-term product upgrades. üîÑ

The adaptations fall into two main categories. First, price considerations dramatically influence technology choices. Just as books on Amazon's Kindle store might cost 5-10 times less in India than in the US, our solutions needed to reflect local economic realities without compromising effectiveness. üí∞

Second, the actual concentration of air pollutants in India is much higher both outdoors and indoors. This creates entirely different technical requirements for our systems. All other product refinements - such as specific widgets, QR codes, or communication protocols - are not India-specific and would emerge similarly in any market. üå´Ô∏è

Our office in Gurugram serves as both a workspace and Experience Center where we demonstrate our technologies to clients. The air quality in our office is 50-100 times better than outside, providing a dramatic demonstration of our capabilities. This physical presence is crucial - clients need to see, touch, and experience our equipment. Having a professional office also builds credibility in the market. üè¢

We chose Delhi after visiting multiple cities including Bangalore and Mumbai. Delhi has the most acute air quality problems (winter there is an ecological disaster) combined with the highest concentration of potential clients. While Mumbai is also a major business center, Delhi offered the optimal combination of need and opportunity. üåç

highlight.title: Extreme Local Conditions Require Complete Product Re-Engineering
highlight.description: Products designed for moderate pollution levels need fundamental redesign for extreme environments like India. Price localization and technical adaptation must happen simultaneously while maintaining effectiveness.

emails.subject: Sales Cycles and Building Credibility ‚è≥
emails.body:
You asked about the transaction cycle and processes in India.

One of the most significant factors affecting business development in India is the extended time frames for everything. The typical time between stages in the sales process or between client contacts is much longer than in other markets. Clients take considerably more time to evaluate and make decisions. ‚è∞

Beyond this general slowness, there's another crucial factor: you need to establish your organization's longevity in the market. If you arrived a year or two ago and might leave in another year or two, potential clients will be hesitant to commit. During our first year, it was nearly impossible to close sales simply because we were new. Now in our second year moving toward our third, we have established a history that makes things easier. üìà

This credibility challenge means you need financial resources and determination to operate without orders for an extended period. You must be prepared to invest in building your presence and reputation before expecting significant commercial returns. üí∞

The trust-building process can't be rushed, and having a strong local partner is essential for navigating these dynamics. Our office, team size (about 30 people), and growing track record all contribute to building the credibility needed for long-term success in this challenging but potentially rewarding market. üè¢

What we've learned is that patience isn't just a virtue in India - it's a business requirement. The companies that succeed here are those that can maintain operations and team morale during extended periods without significant revenue, knowing that once credibility is established, business relationships can become very strong and long-lasting. ü§ù

highlight.title: Market Credibility Takes Years to Build and Cannot Be Accelerated
highlight.description: In trust-based markets like India, being new automatically disqualifies you from major deals regardless of product quality. Plan for 2-3 years of credibility building before expecting significant sales, and budget accordingly.
